sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on The Mayflower Compact. Plymouth Colony and the Pilgrims (1620-1630). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Elizabeth, age 12, a Pilgrim aboard the Mayflower, 1620.

My name is Elizabeth, and I am twelve years old. My family are Separatists—we broke away from the Church of England because we believe it is corrupt. In England, this belief made us criminals. We could be jailed, fined, or worse for refusing to attend the official church.
visuals: Chapter title: Separating from the Church
sections.key_takeaway: My name is Elizabeth, and I am twelve years old.

sections.narration: When we finally sighted land, we faced an immediate problem: we were far north of Virginia, outside the Virginia Company's territory. This meant we had no legal government. Some of the Strangers said they would do as they pleased since no laws bound them here. Our leaders knew this could lead to chaos.
sections.key_takeaway: When we finally sighted land, we faced an immediate problem: we were far north of Virginia, outside the Virginia Company's territory.

sections.narration: We arrived in November, far too late to plant crops. We had to build shelter before winter's full fury struck. The men worked desperately to construct a common house and a few small homes, but progress was slow in the cold. That first winter was our starving time.
sections.key_takeaway: We arrived in November, far too late to plant crops.

sections.narration: In March, an amazing thing happened. A Native American man walked into our settlement and greeted us in English! His name was Samoset, and he brought us to meet Massasoit, the leader of the Wampanoag people. Massasoit brought with him a man named Squanto, whose story was heartbreaking.
sections.key_takeaway: In March, an amazing thing happened.

sections.narration: I am eighteen now, and Plymouth is a real town. We have sturdy houses, productive fields, and enough food stored for winter. More ships bring new settlers each year. We're no longer desperately clinging to survival—we're building a permanent community.
sections.key_takeaway: I am eighteen now, and Plymouth is a real town.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored The Mayflower Compact through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Pilgrims, Separatists, Mayflower, Mayflower Compact.
